But if we look in the past, I assume that if the base in '14 and in full year '13 was probably depressed for North American retail margins, North American segment margins, and if we look back 5, 6 years, it's probable that, that was running in kind of mid- to high single-digits CSOI margins, kind of similar to the incremental margins you just reported for that segment, 8.7%. So I guess the big question I want to ask is, is there a structural change in the North American retail business over the next -- this year and the next couple of years, versus what you had, call it, in 2004 to 2009 when the margins were, I think, pretty clearly higher and now you're going to be recovering to those levels. That's what I'm trying to get at. Any color would be great.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the question, Mark. Just in terms of going forward, we're not giving any specific guidance beyond the current quarter. So I can't predict for you what could happen. But what you mentioned is -- in some of the periods that you were describi
componenttext: Yes, thanks for the question, Mark. Just in terms of going forward, we're not giving any specific guidance beyond the current quarter. So I can't predict for you what could happen. But what you mentioned is -- in some of the periods that you were describing, is you mentioned what our business looked like several years ago when we -- Prime was nascent and we were a bit early in the business. And so we go through different cycles. We're certainly still investing very heavily. That being said, we, as I mentioned last quarter, we're spending time on making sure that we get productivity. So we're working on both investing heavily in the business, we're working on fixed and variable productivity in other areas, putting a lot more energy into it. That's what's helping us with the improvement that Brian mentioned in terms of operating margins year-over-year, there's a number of different aspects, but certainly mix of business and some productivity is certainly impacting that. But again, we think there's opportunities to improve margins over time. You'll have to stay tuned on that to see what it looks like. But we're certainly, as you can see from not only the results but some of the data points that we've given over the last several quarters, we are investing heavily in the business. Again, because we like what we see in Prime growing so dramatically globally after being in it for a long time, and we think that, that's a great platform to feed.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on margins. First, on AWS. I think those are higher than most of us were thinking. Appreciate the disclosure. What is driving your margin versus your pricing decision? How do you think about passing through cost efficiencies or poten
componenttext: A couple of questions on margins. First, on AWS. I think those are higher than most of us were thinking. Appreciate the disclosure. What is driving your margin versus your pricing decision? How do you think about passing through cost efficiencies or potential margin growth through to customers. And then secondly, on international margins, clearly below history, below the U.S. What kind of things need to happen to get those at least to where the U.S. is today, much less back to where they were 6, 7 years ago?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Justin, I'll take the AWS portion of the question first. So our model over the long term really has been to innovate and to use our scale and position to be able to pass savings along to customers. And so we've had 48 price decreases since we launched. As
componenttext: Justin, I'll take the AWS portion of the question first. So our model over the long term really has been to innovate and to use our scale and position to be able to pass savings along to customers. And so we've had 48 price decreases since we launched. As I talked about earlier, that's one factor, customers save a lot of money, but the primary motivator is really around the innovation that AWS enables and the ability for developers to move really quickly.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the international, again, as you mentioned, Justin, we are investing a lot right now, which impacts the margins there, again x exchange, think of it as approximately breakeven for the quarter. And so again, we're continuing to invest. We're in
componenttext: In terms of the international, again, as you mentioned, Justin, we are investing a lot right now, which impacts the margins there, again x exchange, think of it as approximately breakeven for the quarter. And so again, we're continuing to invest. We're investing in all the things that we talked about related to the platform, continue to invest in some emerging geographies, most notably certainly India with the step-up, given the experience we have. And so we are optimistic over time. We have a lot to do there. We think it's a great opportunity for us, and so that's what we're doing. But we're excited about the opportunity, and that's why you see the results that you're seeing there.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us a sense of how we should think about the run rate of CapEx and capital lease obligations in the quarter, as any sort of indication for full year and the trajectory of investment in fulfillment and data centers. And the
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us a sense of how we should think about the run rate of CapEx and capital lease obligations in the quarter, as any sort of indication for full year and the trajectory of investment in fulfillment and data centers. And then just on the question of Prime and Prime video, as we think about the way that media growth is trending now, is there a point where you start to think of allocating Prime -- some of those Prime revenues to media to account for the -- as Prime video usage increases?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the CapEx question, there's certainly 2 pieces of that. There's the consumer, the North America and international piece. There's a number of pieces, but certainly the 2 largest pieces would certainly be the CapEx associated with the fulfi
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the CapEx question, there's certainly 2 pieces of that. There's the consumer, the North America and international piece. There's a number of pieces, but certainly the 2 largest pieces would certainly be the CapEx associated with the fulfillment and the second would be infrastructure. And again, that's for AWS versus North America and international. I'll take the North America and international first. We're seeing good growth, and year-over-year, in terms of overall unit growth, in terms of revenue growth, certainly x exchange, as I mentioned earlier, it's early in the year. So as we do every year, we'll continue to monitor the growth there. We're making plans for the rest of the year, and we'll get back to you as we progress throughout the year in terms of what fulfillment capacity we'll need to support that growth this year. In terms of Web Services, it's obviously growing extremely fast. We saw some acceleration of growth from a revenue perspective. Over the last few quarters here, usage is growing faster than that, so we will be deploying more capital as we go there. In terms of the amounts, specific amounts, we're not giving guidance on that today. And one of the reasons is it's just growing so fast that we want to make sure we put the right amount of capital in place, and the team's done a great job doing all the planning and the execution around that. So that's what we're doing there. In terms of media, I'm not fully sure I understood the question. But as it relates to, I think, it's video, could you repeat that part of the question?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, I was just getting a sense of as video becomes such a -- becomes a bigger part of the Prime value proposition, do you start to allocate some of the annual revenues from Prime more directly into that media segment because of the level of usage assoc
componenttext: Right, I was just getting a sense of as video becomes such a -- becomes a bigger part of the Prime value proposition, do you start to allocate some of the annual revenues from Prime more directly into that media segment because of the level of usage associated with Prime video versus the shipping benefits of Prime.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Heath, we do allocate some Prime to account for the video.
componenttext: Heath, we do allocate some Prime to account for the video.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gene Munster with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gene Munster with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about the focus on same day and same hour, and specifically about the incremental investments and just some context to how big of those investments are? And separately is what the strategic advantage is. Is this something ultim
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about the focus on same day and same hour, and specifically about the incremental investments and just some context to how big of those investments are? And separately is what the strategic advantage is. Is this something ultimately -- obviously, it's to improve the experience, but do you see in any of your data that this opens you up to be more competitive with traditional retailers.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that one. We -- certainly, as I said earlier, we see this as a natural extension of our existing infrastructure investment. With 109 fulfillment centers, we're getting very close to customers. It allows us and locks for us, same-day and nex
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that one. We -- certainly, as I said earlier, we see this as a natural extension of our existing infrastructure investment. With 109 fulfillment centers, we're getting very close to customers. It allows us and locks for us, same-day and next-day deliveries and to its extreme, 1-hour and 2-hour deliveries, as you've seen with Prime Now. So we're not forecasting or giving much more on that, but we definitely see it as a valuable customer proposition. Customers embraced it. Again, a smaller number of ascents [ph], tens of thousands of ascents but available for 1 or 2-hour delivery and generally in the category of essential products that you would need in a short time period.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I would add to that, as Brian mentioned earlier as well, we're in 7 cities today and there'd be more to come. We haven't said how many, but you should be definitely expecting more to come, and we're very excited to do that.
componenttext: And the only thing I would add to that, as Brian mentioned earlier as well, we're in 7 cities today and there'd be more to come. We haven't said how many, but you should be definitely expecting more to come, and we're very excited to do that.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Peck with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Peck with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Tom, could you give us an update on your retail store strategy? Should we expect stores to open up across the U.S. or is that something you guys are limited in trying out in New York? And then number two, India has come up a couple of tim
componenttext: I was wondering, Tom, could you give us an update on your retail store strategy? Should we expect stores to open up across the U.S. or is that something you guys are limited in trying out in New York? And then number two, India has come up a couple of times on the call today. China had several structural challenges, based on the market there. I was curious if you can differentiate what you're seeing that's different in India versus the China challenges.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of our consumer business, we love the business that we have today. We love -- we think there's a great opportunity to do that, to continue to expand the existing business that we have. In terms of other things, we have a longstanding practic
componenttext: Yes, in terms of our consumer business, we love the business that we have today. We love -- we think there's a great opportunity to do that, to continue to expand the existing business that we have. In terms of other things, we have a longstanding practice of not talking about what we might or might not do there. In terms of the second part, India and China, can you repeat that part, sorry?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So you talked about India a couple of times today on the call. Obviously, it's a big area of investment, focus for the company. China has some structural challenges, based on how the marketplace is. I was wondering if you can differentiate what you'
componenttext: Sure. So you talked about India a couple of times today on the call. Obviously, it's a big area of investment, focus for the company. China has some structural challenges, based on how the marketplace is. I was wondering if you can differentiate what you're seeing in India that makes you optimistic there versus some of the challenges you face in China?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you for the question. They are very different. You'll see the growth rate in India is very rapid, as we talked about last year, and it's increasing our investment. I think the biggest difference is the focus on sellers and the connection of sel
componenttext: Yes, thank you for the question. They are very different. You'll see the growth rate in India is very rapid, as we talked about last year, and it's increasing our investment. I think the biggest difference is the focus on sellers and the connection of sellers. A big part of the challenge there is helping sellers all across India to succeed and grow their online businesses. You'll see from our press release that we've launched some new apps for that, so that helps them manage their inventory better and also respond to customer inquiries. So that's probably the biggest difference that we see between India and China, but -- and still very, very early on in India.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So can you talk about how the impact on available third-party SKUs impacts the business, particularly, let's say, in Europe? And ultimately, what you could do to drive more SKUs through the platform, whether it's lowering third-party rates, or are there o
componenttext: So can you talk about how the impact on available third-party SKUs impacts the business, particularly, let's say, in Europe? And ultimately, what you could do to drive more SKUs through the platform, whether it's lowering third-party rates, or are there other factors to try to get more SKUs on there for third-party?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We spent a tremendous amount of time on our seller business over the years and trying to improve both the experience for sellers as well as customers. And we've done a lot of interesting things to help sellers, and that's why you see the results that we'r
componenttext: We spent a tremendous amount of time on our seller business over the years and trying to improve both the experience for sellers as well as customers. And we've done a lot of interesting things to help sellers, and that's why you see the results that we're seeing today. 44% of our units today, as of this quarter, are third-party units. That's up about 400 basis points from last year. Certainly, one of the things that we've talked about that's most -- that's notable is fulfillment by Amazon. And so the benefit for sellers is they get to take advantage of our multinode fulfillment network globally, we have 109 fulfillment centers globally, as well as our customers get to take advantage of that as Prime members where we offer in those geographies. So it's really a great benefit for sellers, it's good for sellers, it's good for customers and we believe good for share owners, too. So again, we're very excited, a number of different things we're working on, but certainly one of the drivers, along with all the things that I mentioned, certainly, FBA is very helpful.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Miller with William Blair & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Miller with William Blair & Company.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Looking at the service sales less the AWS revenues, you've got about $4 billion in fees, mostly coming from the marketplace, up a strong mid-30%. Can you help us think about the cost that go against those marketplace fees? And specifically, within fulfill
componenttext: Looking at the service sales less the AWS revenues, you've got about $4 billion in fees, mostly coming from the marketplace, up a strong mid-30%. Can you help us think about the cost that go against those marketplace fees? And specifically, within fulfillment, if you can help us understand how much of the cost is going against 3P or basically FBA fulfillment, perhaps percent of units, part of the FCs that are going to 3P?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, Mark, I can't comment on the derived number, but I can say that FBA continues to grow really well, it's become a bigger and bigger part of our third-party mix over the years. I think we gave you an update in Q4 that it was more than 40% of our third-p
componenttext: So, Mark, I can't comment on the derived number, but I can say that FBA continues to grow really well, it's become a bigger and bigger part of our third-party mix over the years. I think we gave you an update in Q4 that it was more than 40% of our third-party units. Obviously, in the fulfillment line, there is cost associated with that, as well as our other third-party units as well, with things like payment processing and other costs that we incur. So I don't know if there's much more we can say about that.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I can insert a second question, given the upside and profitability in the first quarter, the guidance for the second quarter, quite a bit lower. What are the factors you see that are negatives or I guess otherwise, people are going to think you're sand
componenttext: If I can insert a second question, given the upside and profitability in the first quarter, the guidance for the second quarter, quite a bit lower. What are the factors you see that are negatives or I guess otherwise, people are going to think you're sandbagging?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let's take a look at the guidance that we gave. Again, we gave -- as we have in previous quarters, we gave a wide range, and from a consolidated segment operating income standpoint, we gave 100 to 650. The implied margin at the lower end to the higher end
componenttext: Let's take a look at the guidance that we gave. Again, we gave -- as we have in previous quarters, we gave a wide range, and from a consolidated segment operating income standpoint, we gave 100 to 650. The implied margin at the lower end to the higher end is approximately 50 basis points upwards to 2.9%. This quarter, in Q1, we're up 60 basis points year-over-year, in total, at the upper end of that forecast, implied would be up 80 basis points. So again, that's the range that we think is appropriate range for Q2.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from Ron Josey with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our final question comes from Ron Josey with JMP Securities.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just going back to margins and a little bit more on AWS. As I look at the seasonality, I wonder if there's any seasonality in margins. It looks like margins in 2Q and 3Q came in sub-10% versus maybe mid-teens in 4Q and 1Q. And then sort of looking at a di
componenttext: Just going back to margins and a little bit more on AWS. As I look at the seasonality, I wonder if there's any seasonality in margins. It looks like margins in 2Q and 3Q came in sub-10% versus maybe mid-teens in 4Q and 1Q. And then sort of looking at a different way, maybe given the dip in profitability in 2Q of last year, did that have any impact from the pricing cuts in April?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let's start with the increase you saw sequentially in margin from Q2 -- or Q3 to Q4 2014. So revenue grew by about 21.5% sequentially and expense grew by around 10%. So obviously, we were growing faster on top line than our expenses. And over the long
componenttext:
So let's start with the increase you saw sequentially in margin from Q2 -- or Q3 to Q4 2014. So revenue grew by about 21.5% sequentially and expense grew by around 10%. So obviously, we were growing faster on top line than our expenses. And over the long term, improvements in efficiency and innovation allow us to drive that kind of cost out of the business. I mean, there certainly was an impact with pricing changes, and you probably saw some of that in Q2 as well. But over the long term, that's the model we follow.
With that, thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greetings. Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Q2 2015 Financial Results Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks, I will be turning the call over to the Director
componenttext: Greetings. Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Q2 2015 Financial Results Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks, I will be turning the call over to the Director of Investor Relations, Phil Hardin. Please go ahead.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to our Q2 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks. The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management'
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to our Q2 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks. 
The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, July 23, 2015 only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially.  Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K. 
As you listen to today's conference call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary of the quarter. 
During this call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website. You will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures.  Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2014. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Phil. I'll begin the comments on our second quarter financial results. Trailing 12-month operating cash flow increased 69% to $8.98 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow increased to $4.37 billion, up from $1.04 billion. In the supplemental fi
componenttext:
Thanks, Phil. I'll begin the comments on our second quarter financial results. Trailing 12-month operating cash flow increased 69% to $8.98 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow increased to $4.37 billion, up from $1.04 billion. In the supplemental financial information and business metrics portion of our earnings release, we include a few additional cash flow measures. We believe these measures provide additional perspective on the impact of acquiring property and equipment with cash and capital and finance leases.
Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $4.61 billion. Capital expenditures do not include the impact of property and equipment acquired under capital and finance lease obligations.  The increase in capital expenditures and capital leases reflects additional investments in support of continued business growth due to investments in technology infrastructure, the majority of which is to support AWS and additional capacity to support our fulfillment operations. 
Return on invested capital was 17%, up from 6%. ROIC is trailing 12-month free cash flow divided by average total assets minus current liabilities, excluding the current portion of long-term debt over 5 quarter ends.
The combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 488 million shares compared with 480 million  1 year ago. 
Worldwide revenue grew 20% to $23.18 billion, or 27% excluding the $1.39 billion unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange.  Worldwide paid unit growth was 22%. 
Worldwide active customer accounts was approximately 285 million. Excluding customers who only had 3 orders in the preceding 12-month period, worldwide active customers were approximately 265 million, up from approximately 237 million in the comparable prior year period. 
Worldwide seller units represented 45% of paid units, up from 41% in the comparable prior year period.
Now I'll discuss operating expenses excluding stock-based compensation. Cost of sales was $15.16 billion or 65.4% of revenue compared to 69.3%.
Fulfillment, marketing, technology and content and G&A combined was $6.95 billion or 29.9% of sales, up approximately 130 basis points year-over-year. Fulfillment was $2.74 billion or 11.8% of revenue compared with 11.8%. Tech and content was $2.70 billion or 11.7% of revenue compared with 10.4%. Marketing was $1.1 billion or 4.7% of revenue compared with 4.7%.
Now I'll talk about our segment results. As a reminder, in the first quarter, we changed our reportable segments will reflect North America, international and Amazon Web Services. Consistent with prior periods, we do not allocate to segments our stock-based allocation, but the other operating expense line item.
In the North America segment, revenue grew 26% to $13.8 billion. Media revenue grew 6% to $2.62 billion or 7% excluding foreign exchange. EGM revenue grew 31% to $10.99 billion or 32% excluding foreign exchange. EGM now represents 80% of North America revenues.  North America segment operating income increased 113% to $703 million, a 5.1% operating margin. Excluding the $9 million favorable impact from foreign exchange, North America segment operating income increased 111%.
In the international segment, revenue increased 3% to $7.56 billion. Excluding the $1.37 billion year-over-year unfavorable impact from foreign exchange, revenue growth was 22%. Media revenue decreased 12% to $2.09 billion or increased 3% excluding foreign exchange. EGM revenue grew 10% to $5.43 billion or 31% excluding foreign exchange. EGM now represents 72% of international revenues.  International segment operating loss was $19 million compared to a loss of $2 million in the prior year period. International segment operating loss includes $89 million of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange. 
In the Amazon Web Services segment, revenue increased 81% to $1.82 billion. Amazon Web Services segment operating income increased 407% to $391 million, a 21.4% operating margin. Excluding the $71 million favorable impact from foreign exchange, AWS segment operating income increased 314%.
Consolidated segment operating income increased 166% to $1.07 billion or 4.6% of revenue, up approximately 250 basis points year-over-year. Excluding the $9 million unfavorable impact from foreign exchange, CSOI increased 168%. 
Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation expense and other operating expense. GAAP operating income was $464 million compared to a loss of $15 million in the prior year period.
Our income tax expense was $266 million. GAAP net income was $92 million or $0.19 per diluted share compared with a net loss of $126 million or a loss of $0.27 per diluted share.
Coming to the balance sheet. Cash and marketable securities increased $6.02 billion year-over-year to $14 billion. Inventory increased 12% to $7.4 billion. And inventory turns were 8.9, down from 9.1 turns a year ago as we expanded selection, improved in-stock levels and introduced new product categories.  Accounts payable increased 18% to $12.39 billion. And accounts payable days increased to 74 from 71 in the prior year.
I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our guid are the order trends that we've seen to date in what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors, including a high level of uncertainty surrounding exchange rate fluctuations as well as the global economy and customer spending. It's not possible to accurately predict demand. And therefore, actual results could differ materially from our guidance. 
As we described in more detail in our public filings, issues such as  settling intercompany balances in foreign currency among our subsidiaries, unfavorable resolution of legal matters and changes to our effective tax rate can all have material effect on guidance. The guidance further assumes that we don't conclude any additional business acquisitions, investments, restructurings or legal settlements, recording any further revisions to stock-based compensation estimates, and that foreign exchange rates remain approximately where they have been recently.
For Q3 2015, we expect net sales of between $23.3 billion and $25.5 billion, or growth of between 13% and 24%. This guidance anticipates approximately 620 basis points of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates. GAAP operating income or loss to be between a $480 million loss and $70 million of income compared to a $544 million loss in the third quarter of 2014. This includes approximately $580 million for stock-based compensation and amortization of intangible assets.
We anticipate consolidated segment operating income, which excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense, to be between $100 million and $650 million compared to a $136 million loss in the third quarter of 2014.
We remain hands-down focused on driving better customer experience through price, selection and convenience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholders. 
Thanks. And with that, Phil, let's move on to questions.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Brian. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question?
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Brian. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly. [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from Mark May with Citi.
componenttext: Certainly. [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from Mark May with Citi.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Clearly, a lot of things that were working well in the quarter, but maybe just focusing on AWS, which is since quickly emerging as kind of your largest contributor to operating income. Can you maybe provide a little more color on what drove the accelerati
componenttext: Clearly, a lot of things that were working well in the quarter, but maybe just focusing on AWS, which is since quickly emerging as kind of your largest contributor to operating income. Can you maybe provide a little more color on what drove the acceleration and just the overall growth of the business, if you could talk a little bit about the addition of new customers versus average spend per customer? And I think in the past, you've talked about but unit growth was for AWS. And then in the press release, you talked about expanding AWS into some international markets. Can you give us a feel for how much of AWS business today is domestic, and kind of what kind of opportunity you have there to expand AWS outside the U.S.?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. Thanks for your question. So we will not be providing the granular customer detail unfortunately. But I will say the growth of 81% was up from 49% in Q1. You remember that we're lapping a number of large price decreases in Q2 of last year, so i
componenttext: Yes, Mark. Thanks for your question. So we will not be providing the granular customer detail unfortunately. But I will say the growth of 81% was up from 49% in Q1. You remember that we're lapping a number of large price decreases in Q2 of last year, so it was somewhat expected. But very strong quarter in AWS. We did open a region in India, .  The other thing to mention is we continue to see strong usage growth that's outpacing revenue growth of 81% obviously. And so we're really excited about it. From a distribution of customers, it is a global business. We have regions spread throughout the world. We've got 11 regions at this point and have announced plans to launch a region in India in the future.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's been some recent press reports talking about investments in India. I wanted to know, you talked a little bit about that more kind of in the past, whether there is any update there in terms of what you think about approaching that market and the le
componenttext: There's been some recent press reports talking about investments in India. I wanted to know, you talked a little bit about that more kind of in the past, whether there is any update there in terms of what you think about approaching that market and the levels of investments that might be needed to compete in the market?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, Eric. What I'd like to say about India is that when we see a positive surprise, we double down on it. That's kind of our policy. and India is that kind of surprise. So we're very happy, very encouraged early on with what we've seen in the rampi
componenttext: Certainly, Eric. What I'd like to say about India is that when we see a positive surprise, we double down on it. That's kind of our policy. and India is that kind of surprise. So we're very happy, very encouraged early on with what we've seen in the ramping of the business, the level of retention going on for both customers and sellers. Over $25 million -- I'm sorry, 25 million   we're just the largest online store in India, and continue to improve pricing and fast delivery. So we're super excited about India. We'll not get into specific investment numbers right now, but we continue to ramp up our investment there.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple questions. We probably saw this coming for a long time, and profits seemed to move around quite a bit year-over-year. And year against year-end. I'm just wondering how you think about that. Is that the nature of your big bets and that's just goin
componenttext: A couple questions. We probably saw this coming for a long time, and profits seemed to move around quite a bit year-over-year. And year against year-end. I'm just wondering how you think about that. Is that the nature of your big bets and that's just going to to continue? Or is there a way to kind of smooth that out? And secondly in AWS, it does seem like pricing competition has come down. And we've been to a lot of your events, and seems like you're emphasizing pricing a little less to your customers. Can you talk about the pricing environment in cloud?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start with that second question. So as Phil mentioned, we're seeing continued increases in usage both sequentially and year-over-year, but we're also seeing that efficiency in a business on a cost basis. Innovation is accelerating, not decele
componenttext: Sure. Let me start with that second question. So as Phil mentioned, we're seeing continued increases in usage both sequentially and year-over-year, but we're also seeing that efficiency in a business on a cost basis. Innovation is accelerating, not decelerating. We had over 350 significant new features and services. And maybe that's what customers -- resonates with customers. While pricing is certainly a factor, we don't believe it's always the primary factor. In fact, what we hear from our customers is that the ability to move faster and more agile is what they value. I'm sorry, the first part of your question was?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was asking about just how the profitability kind of moves pretty big swings year-over-year. Is that a nature of just your big bets and that can continue? Or is there a way to kind of smooth that out going forward? How do you think about that?
componenttext: Yes, I was asking about just how the profitability kind of moves pretty big swings year-over-year. Is that a nature of just your big bets and that can continue? Or is there a way to kind of smooth that out going forward? How do you think about that?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. This is how we think about it. We have 2 things, at least 2 things going on. We're continuing to drive operational improvement in every business that we're in. But we're also investing in larger opportunities that are in front of us, particular
componenttext: Yes, sure. This is how we think about it. We have 2 things, at least 2 things going on. We're continuing to drive operational improvement in every business that we're in. But we're also investing in larger opportunities that are in front of us, particularly in Marketplace, Prime and AWS. If you saw our shareholder letter this year, I think Jeff Bezos put it very well. He said we're going to look for things that are important to customers. Customers love them businesses that can grow to be a large size, that can generate a higher return on invested capital and are durable and can last for decades. So we will continue to invest in the business that we think fit that profile. And we're always looking for a fourth or fifth business that fits that profile. So as far as lumpiness, it really is lumpy. And we will continue to work on both those tracks going forward.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if Tom's listening in. That's a great exit on his part. The on international retail, you had nice acceleration. Can you give us a little bit more of the why behind that? Why would the EGM accelerate materially? And is that impact, is one thes
componenttext: I don't know if Tom's listening in. That's a great exit on his part. The on international retail, you had nice acceleration. Can you give us a little bit more of the why behind that? Why would the EGM accelerate materially? And is that impact, is one thesis is the impact of kind of the buildup of Prime in international markets and also in the U.S. too? But more spend per Prime customers as they go through this revolution is just of on? Is that what it is? What is that causing that acceleration?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly. We saw good acceleration in both North America and international this quarter. North America was up 200 basis points sequentially, and international was up 800 basis points. And half of that, you remember, we've spoken about the impact of the J
componenttext: Certainly. We saw good acceleration in both North America and international this quarter. North America was up 200 basis points sequentially, and international was up 800 basis points. And half of that, you remember, we've spoken about the impact of the Japanese consumption tax that was instituted last April 1 of 2014. It had a measurable impact on our run rate, our growth rate last year particularly i Q2. And so we're lapping that, which sequentially makes up half of the 800 basis point sequential again, so -- but independent of that, yes, you're right. Prime membership continues to grow faster outside -- at least in the data we gave you at the end of year, it's growing faster outside the U.S. than it is in the U.S.. But we're happy with both growth rates, quite frankly. I would say the Prime membership, the Prime flywheel, the additional benefits we're adding to Prime, not only North America but also internationally, and additional selection both retail and FBA, which it fits the Prime flywheel.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have two, the first one on the North America retail. Profitability was up nicely. Can you just talk to some of the drivers of that? Is it more top line and more Prime subs coming on? Or is more on logistics side? And what's driving the North American im
componenttext: I have two, the first one on the North America retail. Profitability was up nicely. Can you just talk to some of the drivers of that? Is it more top line and more Prime subs coming on? Or is more on logistics side? And what's driving the North American improving profitability? And then the international profitability, is there any way you can help us understand the profitability of the more mature international markets like U.K.  And Germany relative to the U.S. at this point?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let me start with North America. 5.1% operating margin, it was up from 3.9% in Q1 and 3% last Q2. You hit a nail on the head. A lot of that is the top line growth, but it's also a lot of efficiency we're seeing, particularly on fulfillment and ma
componenttext: Sure. So let me start with North America. 5.1% operating margin, it was up from 3.9% in Q1 and 3% last Q2. You hit a nail on the head. A lot of that is the top line growth, but it's also a lot of efficiency we're seeing, particularly on fulfillment and marketing lines, which for the whole company were flat year-over-year on a percent of revenue basis. So we are getting good top line growth. A lot of guys feel that Prime, Prime adoption. And we are dropping a lot to the bottom line with maybe efficiency projects. In international, we have not split countries out. What I can say is if you adjust for foreign exchange, the operating margin is up slightly versus sequentially and year-over-year. What you're seeing there is also obviously colored by investment or our thesis investment in India based on the momentum and success that we've seeing there so far.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Doug Anmuth of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Doug Anmuth of JPMorgan.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just two things I wanted to ask. First on Prime Day, Brian. if you could give a little color there on the early takeaways that you have? And then perhaps more importantly, how you think that sets Amazon up for the back-to-school season and then also the h
componenttext: Just two things I wanted to ask. First on Prime Day, Brian. if you could give a little color there on the early takeaways that you have? And then perhaps more importantly, how you think that sets Amazon up for the back-to-school season and then also the holidays later in the year? And then also, can you just comment on the headcount, which I believe is up 18,000 or so sequentially, which I believe is the biggest number that you've ever added in a quarter. Is there anything in particular that stands out there? Were they just more fulfillment centers, more geography expansion as well?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start with that second question first. Yes, headcount was up 38% year-over-year. The vast majority of that is in operations where we're adding people for our new SCs and call centers. We continue to look for smart, innovative people who want to bui
componenttext: Let me start with that second question first. Yes, headcount was up 38% year-over-year. The vast majority of that is in operations where we're adding people for our new SCs and call centers. We continue to look for smart, innovative people who want to build on behalf of customers. And so for this particular quarter is colored a bit by operations growth. If you look at Prime Day, we're thrilled with the results of Prime Day, surpassed all of our expectations. Any metric we looked at, we think it was a huge success. Customers saved millions. New Prime members signed up in higher rate than we've ever seen. People bought more devices than on any other day. So it's a great success. My hats off to the operations team and all the people who worked on that. Because it was a Christmas in July, quite frankly, bigger day than Black Friday as we said and orders increased 266% year-over-year. I'll also point out that worldwide unit growth approached 300%. So not only was it a great day for Amazon, it was also a great day for our sellers, which is great. So while not breaking out the impact of Prime Day specifically, it's incorporated into our guidance.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have two. I may be delusional, but if I add your capital leases and CapEx, that suggests that AWS capital intensity is at least 80%, if not much higher. What gives you confidence that as AWS continues to grow so fast and consuming so much capital, 2 yea
componenttext: I have two. I may be delusional, but if I add your capital leases and CapEx, that suggests that AWS capital intensity is at least 80%, if not much higher. What gives you confidence that as AWS continues to grow so fast and consuming so much capital, 2 years out, you'll be able to fund its growth from the retail business? And secondly, can you help me understand why you are not rolling out Prime Now in Fresh ? What specifically are the bottlenecks there?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start to the second one. Prime Now you said and AmazonFresh, we are moving very quickly on Prime Now.  We have announced in 9 cities, 3 more in the quarter including our first international city in London. So we're moving quick, but we've always li
componenttext: Let me start to the second one. Prime Now you said and AmazonFresh, we are moving very quickly on Prime Now.  We have announced in 9 cities, 3 more in the quarter including our first international city in London. So we're moving quick, but we've always liked to move quicker, obviously. On AWS, I think your question is more around the ability to fund AWS. No comment specifically on that. We do realize it's capital-intensive business. And we have, modeling that, shows it is a very good business for us, and that's where we aim for is long-term return on invested capital and free cash flow. So simply cognizant of that part of the calculation, so not much that to that, Carlos.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you can touch a little bit more on AWS margins. Is there a level particularly when you been able to maintain pricing strength the way that you have been? Or you feel like margin start to become and that the leverage that you have their start
componenttext: Wondering if you can touch a little bit more on AWS margins. Is there a level particularly when you been able to maintain pricing strength the way that you have been? Or you feel like margin start to become and that the leverage that you have their start to become a catalyst for lowering prices? Or is that purely a competitive position? And as you think about sort of AWS longer term, is there a framework for structure that you use to think about where margins in that this should be?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks for your question, Heath. Yes, I'll point out that we have continued to lower prices and have multiple price cuts this year. We're now up to 49 since launch in 2006. So it is a fundamental part of our business model. So is innovation. And as
componenttext: Sure. Thanks for your question, Heath. Yes, I'll point out that we have continued to lower prices and have multiple price cuts this year. We're now up to 49 since launch in 2006. So it is a fundamental part of our business model. So is innovation. And as I said, were have with through the new features and services also significant features and services that launched this year. And we are just talking with Carlos, the capital investment is very large as well. So we continue to fund it, and we're super excited with customer reception that we're getting and the feedback we get from large customers and so were thrilled with the business, and a price reductions are part of that model. And again as I said earlier, we're in the long haul -- we're in this for the long haul. We're looking for return on invested capital, free cash flow and happy customers in this space.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: next question comes from Youssef Squali from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: next question comes from Youssef Squali from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess another question on AWS if I may. So I want to go back to something that you said, Brian. You said that you've seen greater efficiency in that business from a cost standpoint. I was wondering if you can maybe parts that out a little more for us. W
componenttext: I guess another question on AWS if I may. So I want to go back to something that you said, Brian. You said that you've seen greater efficiency in that business from a cost standpoint. I was wondering if you can maybe parts that out a little more for us. We're you referring to OpEx. Hold to CapEx as well. Do you feel that you reach that skate the velocity that should allow CapEx percentage revenues pricing decide to now allow you for constant decline in that metric, CapEx as a percentage in that particular business.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. What I can say is we are seeing greater efficiency in the cost side, the cost to generate capacity for AWS. I will also say that Amazon is one of the primary large customers of AWS. So we see it on the consumer side of the business as well, althoug
componenttext: Right. What I can say is we are seeing greater efficiency in the cost side, the cost to generate capacity for AWS. I will also say that Amazon is one of the primary large customers of AWS. So we see it on the consumer side of the business as well, although that's not include in AWS revenue. It's an intercompany relationship. So we get a double whammy there. We're getting great efficiency from external AWS business, but also from our use of AWS services.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ron Josey from JMP Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ron Josey from JMP Securities.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on the Heath's question just on the price reductions you said earlier in the year. Can you compare maybe the reductions earlier this year versus the ones across the board from last year in 2Q '14? And then a follow-up just the third
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on the Heath's question just on the price reductions you said earlier in the year. Can you compare maybe the reductions earlier this year versus the ones across the board from last year in 2Q '14? And then a follow-up just the third-party units, I think you mentioned third-party units are now 45% or maybe 47% of total units. Is there a natural limit there? Or does it matter as long as the customer experience through FBA is seamless?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ron, so I'll comment on the units first. We're really following of giving customers as many choices as many possible and letting them choose whether they want to buy first party or third party. And I think we're working hard to make sellers succeed on the
componenttext: Ron, so I'll comment on the units first. We're really following of giving customers as many choices as many possible and letting them choose whether they want to buy first party or third party. And I think we're working hard to make sellers succeed on the platform. Brian touched on the success that our FBA sellers had with Prime Day. But we see FBA as a tailwind for the third-party business in general. When we surveyed those sellers in the past in 2014, about 71% of sellers saw a 20% or greater increase in sales when they entered the FBA program. So we're really happy with what that for our third-party business. We're working really hard to give our customers as many options as possible and allowing them to choose. We don't really have a specific target there. It all comes down to customer choice.  On the price reduction question, we've got a long track record of driving costs out of the business. And you can certainly see where we've even done that over the last several quarters if you look at the margins at AWS. We've also lowered prices for customers 40 times since launch. And so it could be lumpy, but over the long haul, that's the model we've followed.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul from Barclays Capital.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the content side. Just any update on how engaged folks are use the video side of Prime and their shopping behavior, number one. Number two, just any updates on sort of your plans for growth on the content cost side.
componenttext: Just a question on the content side. Just any update on how engaged folks are use the video side of Prime and their shopping behavior, number one. Number two, just any updates on sort of your plans for growth on the content cost side.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the engagement of Prime customers, we -- or excuse me, customers. We've seen buying habits that look like Prime customers or other Prime customers from the group that comes through the digital pipelines. But we do also see a higher pickup in rete
componenttext: Sure. On the engagement of Prime customers, we -- or excuse me, customers. We've seen buying habits that look like Prime customers or other Prime customers from the group that comes through the digital pipelines. But we do also see a higher pickup in retention rates and free trial conversions. So we're very happy with the linkage between our digital offerings and the Prime customer base. On the content side, I will say that one of the factors in the sequential guidance Q2 to Q3 being lower is 2 things that bring it up. What we're talking about is the fulfillment center, additional fulfillment center that are costs we see every - this time every year as we get ready for Q4, but also additional step up in content spend, where we spend a lot of our content in Q3. you'll see extensions of a lot of the successful shows that we've had so far this year, a new pilot season including Man in High Castle and Hand of God, so stay tuned for that, for seasons of Man in High Castle and Hand of God.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gene Munster from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gene Munster from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on a previous question. In past calls, you've talked about an increased focus on productivity. Is that still a focus of yours? And separately, any thoughts in terms of how robotics are impacting? Any update in terms of number of r
componenttext: I just want to follow up on a previous question. In past calls, you've talked about an increased focus on productivity. Is that still a focus of yours? And separately, any thoughts in terms of how robotics are impacting? Any update in terms of number of robots in fulfillment centers?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure thing. Thanks for your question, Gene. On robotics first, we don't have any numbers to share with you, but we're super excited with the progress of that business. We had very high expectations for Amazon robotics and its impact on our warehouse cost
componenttext: Sure thing. Thanks for your question, Gene. On robotics first, we don't have any numbers to share with you, but we're super excited with the progress of that business. We had very high expectations for Amazon robotics and its impact on our warehouse cost structure. And we've been very pleasantly surprised by the job being done on that -- by that team. So that's looking great. Efficiency, yes, as we talked about in the last few calls, we have even more emphasis on variable and fixed productivity. I think that's evident in the Q2 results that you've just seen. To give you a little more color on that, I would say, what does that look like? With defect reduction and process improvements are maybe something we've always done and worked on both to lower our costs, but also improve the customer experience and also the seller and vendor experience. We're using software and algorithms to make decisions rather than people. We think it's more efficient and scales better and will be more accurate,  especially as we insert machine learning into those decisions. We said earlier we benefit from the efficiency gains of the AWS business as on the Amazon side as well. We look to increase the leverage of our fixed assets, particularly our performance centers and throughput of the performance centers. And just generally getting inventory closer to customers as we add and expand warehouses and our sort centers that we added primarily last year, all have helped our cost structure, so just a little more color on just on the specifics of the efficiency area.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Pitz with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Pitz with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Now halfway through 2015, any update or insights on your fulfillment center build-out plans for the year? If you can't disclose that, can give us just a general sense of focus and strategy? How should we thinking about domestic versus international as wel
componenttext: Now halfway through 2015, any update or insights on your fulfillment center build-out plans for the year? If you can't disclose that, can give us just a general sense of focus and strategy? How should we thinking about domestic versus international as well as versus traditional? What's kind of the path to build out over the next 6 to 12, 18 months?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we ended the year last year with 109 fulfillment centers around the world and 19 U.S. sort centers. And typically, we're looking at what the demand would be for peak as we figure out what we need, so -- But it's a little early in the year to comm
componenttext: Sure. So we ended the year last year with 109 fulfillment centers around the world and 19 U.S. sort centers. And typically, we're looking at what the demand would be for peak as we figure out what we need, so -- But it's a little early in the year to comment on that, but in the past we've given an update sometime around Q3 on that. But continuing to build as we have demand. And like Brian said, we have to be close to customers and benefit from having inventory close to customers as well. So like I said, a little early for us to update at this point, but something we're looking and something that the teams are working hard on.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Colin Sebastian with Equity Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Colin Sebastian with Equity Research.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the retail business, obviously a lot of variables driving growth there. You've seen higher Prime membership levels for one. But I'm wondering how much of that growth you can also break down by some other factors. For example, we're seeing a notable in
componenttext: And the retail business, obviously a lot of variables driving growth there. You've seen higher Prime membership levels for one. But I'm wondering how much of that growth you can also break down by some other factors. For example, we're seeing a notable increase in selection across longer tail categories. And then secondly, in the press release, no mention of Fire phone. I think almost every other product was mentioned. Can we just chalk that one up to learning experience and an example of where Amazon is showing some discipline around investments? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll start with the Fire phone question. We have a policy of not commenting on the road map, so I can't give you anything there. We obviously do learn from everything we do and value the feedback that that we get from customers, but nothing to share at
componenttext: So I'll start with the Fire phone question. We have a policy of not commenting on the road map, so I can't give you anything there. We obviously do learn from everything we do and value the feedback that that we get from customers, but nothing to share at this point. In terms of growth, we continue to see selection as a strong driver of growth. Prime is obviously very important as well. We really haven't teased those apart if. FBA becomes very important as well. We thought brought about some of the tailwinds we see there and sort of the linkage between Marketplace and Prime that FBA provides. So all of those things are going on. As you've seen, EGM strength across a lot of the categories there. There was no single category we are really calling out , but continue to see good selection growth and good Prime growth as well.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ross Sandler with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ross Sandler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, I know you guys don't like to provide guidance beyond the next quarter. But philosophically, if we go back a few quarters, you characterized 2015 as a year where you believe that some of the heavier investments made in prior years start to benefit
componenttext: Brian, I know you guys don't like to provide guidance beyond the next quarter. But philosophically, if we go back a few quarters, you characterized 2015 as a year where you believe that some of the heavier investments made in prior years start to benefit and pay off? And then we're clearly seeing that in AWS and in North American retail. looks like you're still heavily investing in international retail do. So as we kind of look out to 2016, 2017, is there any high level physical commentary about whether you see you next year as another year of these types of trends that you're seeing now? Or are there any bigger investment areas, particularly in the retail business, that you might be looking to take advantage of?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks for your question. Yes, I can't forecast into the future on that. But I will reiterate the investments we have going on right now, which again, we're looking to invest to strengthen the Prime platform. That includes video content, including the Ama
componenttext: Thanks for your question. Yes, I can't forecast into the future on that. But I will reiterate the investments we have going on right now, which again, we're looking to invest to strengthen the Prime platform. That includes video content, including the Amazon originals, Prime Music, Prime Now. We have a robust device business including a launch of our new paper-light, Fire TV Echo with ability, and numerous other products that we're very excited about that road map. We know that those devices drive customer engagement in sales. We build fulfillment centers so that we can add selection and we can add FBA partners. And then we have things like same-day delivery, which we talked about. On the side, we continue to invest in that infrastructure. We talked about opening -- announcing a region in India, so there's expansion as well. Feature expansion, service expansion international, very similar to the U.S. on the number the Prime front, but also the investment in India. And a few other things you may have seen in our press release today, the launch of Mexico, which we're excited about an Amazon business. So lots of -- as I said, lots of investment in front of us, but we operate in 2 paths. we are definitely working for operational efficiencies in the business that we're in. We're investing wisely in things that we think are big and important. It's not a static activity. We continue to evaluate these investments, take into account what customer response is and make changes. So I think you can look forward to a continuation of that in the future.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kerry Rice with Needham & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kerry Rice with Needham & Company.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: You've talked a lot about operational efficiencies. I know you guys are partnered with the post office and deliveries. Can you talk a bit about how that is potentially benefiting and maybe the longer-term strategy with the post office? And then, you guys
componenttext: You've talked a lot about operational efficiencies. I know you guys are partnered with the post office and deliveries. Can you talk a bit about how that is potentially benefiting and maybe the longer-term strategy with the post office? And then, you guys haven't necessarily broken this out, but I think you do generate a fair amount of revenue from advertising. I think that's in the other category. Is there anything that you can provide on advertising revenue?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'll start with the first part of that question. We definitely are delivering a lot of packages with the post office. I think most notably, they did a lot of the Sunday delivery that you saw when we started launching Sunday delivery. So we try lo
componenttext: Sure. So I'll start with the first part of that question. We definitely are delivering a lot of packages with the post office. I think most notably, they did a lot of the Sunday delivery that you saw when we started launching Sunday delivery. So we try lots of things with fulfillment. We're constantly working to provide the best experience to customers and be as efficient as possible. And so we're happy with all the partners we have and continue to work with them to provide the best experience possible. For advertising, I would remind you that certain parts of the advertising roll up into Other. Some actually roll up to the EGM and media as well. So it's a business we're really excited about. We're taking a customer-centric approach as we build that to make sure that we're providing engaging business and gauging ads to customers and making sure we keep the customer front of mind. And it's a business that the team is excited about and are working hard on.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Chu from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Chu from Crdit Suisse.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the India question earlier. I mean, to my knowledge, I mean foreign e-commerce operators such as yourself are not allowed to have first party retail operations. But given the fulfillment and hence, customer service has always been the
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the India question earlier. I mean, to my knowledge, I mean foreign e-commerce operators such as yourself are not allowed to have first party retail operations. But given the fulfillment and hence, customer service has always been the high-focus item for you guys, what steps have you taken in the country to make sure that the consumer experience there is as good, if not better for the inventory on which you have no direct control? And secondarily, I mean similar to China, you have pretty large population base and Internet penetration growth that is probably comparable to what was the case when you had Joy or when you acquired Joy . Can you provide any color on how the general operating environments are the same or different? And do you expect your growth trajectory there to be similar to what you saw in China?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So your first question was about the infrastructure and how we're managing the customer experience in India. So FBA, easy ship and some of those programs are important to us. They're very valuable for sellers. They make it easy for the seller to get their
componenttext: So your first question was about the infrastructure and how we're managing the customer experience in India. So FBA, easy ship and some of those programs are important to us. They're very valuable for sellers. They make it easy for the seller to get their goods to the customer. They're great from a customer experience standpoint because we can do what we do best with the logistics. And so there's a lot of investments, a lot of efforts going on in that front. I would say India and China are totally different. And I think as Brian mentioned, India is a country that we're doubling down on based on the success we're seeing there so far. so very happy with the trajectory we're on there and excited to be investing and to have the opportunities we do at that point.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Blackledge from Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Blackledge from Cowen & Company.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it appears that Amazon is growing its share of household budget driven by many factors, Prime growth and strong growth in large verticals like apparel, among others. Specifically on apparel, just wondering how you view the breadth of Amazon's apparel o
componenttext: So it appears that Amazon is growing its share of household budget driven by many factors, Prime growth and strong growth in large verticals like apparel, among others. Specifically on apparel, just wondering how you view the breadth of Amazon's apparel offering, any color on that segment's performance in the second quarter? And how do you view Amazon's apparel opportunity going forward?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for your question. We have not broken out specifically apparel, but we're super excited about that business. It's growing very well. We like our position in it. We think our website is very, very attuned to selling online. So we're very happy
componenttext: Yes, thanks for your question. We have not broken out specifically apparel, but we're super excited about that business. It's growing very well. We like our position in it. We think our website is very, very attuned to selling online. So we're very happy with that. It is a big business for us, not only in North America but also internationally. So you mentioned a couple other consumables categories. I will say we are very happy in our consumables and hardlines categories as well. We drive a lot of repeat business within like Prime Pantry and Subscribe And Save and others. So very happy with the EGM business as a whole.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from Scott Tillman with B. Riley.
componenttext: And our final question comes from Scott Tillman with B. Riley.

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just follow up on a couple things, three quick questions. first off on international, just wondering if you could compare and contrast the relative performance of media and EGM moving in different directions. Second, there have been a couple o
componenttext: I wanted to just follow up on a couple things, three quick questions. first off on international, just wondering if you could compare and contrast the relative performance of media and EGM moving in different directions. Second, there have been a couple of questions about shipping. But most notable is that we had a couple price increases from the majors hit at the beginning of the year, and it seems like your costs are coming down. I wondering if you can comment on that. And then third is following up on Brian's questions around the FCs. I'm just wondering how many of the facilities lend themselves to an expansion rather than having to put up a new facility?

headline: Amazon.com Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start with the first question on international media and EGM. I think we're seeing similar trends in both geographies and segments that EGM growth is much -- is very strong. Media growth has been consistent for the last 4 quarters. We do like
componenttext: Sure. Let me start with the first question on international media and EGM. I think we're seeing similar trends in both geographies and segments that EGM growth is much -- is very strong. Media growth has been consistent for the last 4 quarters. We do like the work being done in -- by the media teams. There's a lot of pipeline of invention, things like Prime and Video, Prime Music. Off , the Prime pipeline and Prime ecosystem, if you will, they work great with our devices, by the way. And they drive other nonmedia sales. So they're very tied together, although certainly, the EGM is outpacing the media segment and the media businesses right now. On transportation costs, not a lot to add there.
