componenttext: Some questions on video. Any color such as engagement on the recent launch of video products in Japan, including the Fire TV, the Fire TV and Prime video. And also, any general updates on your video content strategy or view on stand-alone streaming separate from Prime?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that one. This is Brian. So no specific callouts in Japan. I would say that we are still very bullish on our Prime Instant Video that the expect our new original constantly created. It's been critically acclaimed and with customers. Man in
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that one. This is Brian. So no specific callouts in Japan. I would say that we are still very bullish on our Prime Instant Video that the expect our new original constantly created. It's been critically acclaimed and with customers. Man in Highcastle is coming out shortly as is the second season of Transparent, which won Emmys this year. So really excited about the creative team we assembled and the product that we've been able to bring to Prime customers. And we still love the customer reaction. Free trial conversion rates are higher when Prime members stream. And they also renew at a higher rate for their annual subscriptions. So again, that's very important to us as well and very happy with the results.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Ben Schachter with Macquarie equity research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Prime has done remarkably well with folks who pay $99 up front. Would you expect to have different offerings for different cohorts? In other words, right now, Prime is sort of a one size fits all model. Could we see different pricing models for different
componenttext: Prime has done remarkably well with folks who pay $99 up front. Would you expect to have different offerings for different cohorts? In other words, right now, Prime is sort of a one size fits all model. Could we see different pricing models for different demographics in the future? And then separately, can you talk about how shipping leverage changes during the holiday season when shoppers tend to order more items per transaction?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So this is Phil. On the Prime pricing, we do have a few different programs for different demographic today with programs like Prime Student or Prime Family, which we're preparing, which we're very excited about. I can't speculate as to what we'll do
componenttext: Sure. So this is Phil. On the Prime pricing, we do have a few different programs for different demographic today with programs like Prime Student or Prime Family, which we're preparing, which we're very excited about. I can't speculate as to what we'll do in the future, but Prime is a program that's really important for us. And we're working hard every day to continue to build selection there and to continue to make Prime better. So hopefully, you should see that in the things we launched recently and kind of continued cadence of making the services we have better. We just added a lot of new music and our Prime Music program. And as Brian mentioned, some of the upcoming programming should be pretty good in the fall that the Man in the Highcastle are mostly watched by that. So we're excited about that one as well. So continue to work on Prime. On the shipping side, yes, I would say it's a difficult equation. Yes, order size can go up. But we ship a lot of toys and bigger items, so it's hard to predict what that looks like. But having the density, having the sort centers has certainly helped our cost rupture in that area and having inventory closer to our customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Ju with Credit Suisse.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, it seems like you guys are rolling out Prime Mow and product verticals internationally quickly, especially if you measure it versus a pace for Fresh or your other international older territories. So am I reading too much into this? Or have you guys
componenttext: Brian, it seems like you guys are rolling out Prime Mow and product verticals internationally quickly, especially if you measure it versus a pace for Fresh or your other international older territories. So am I reading too much into this? Or have you guys put in place different processes to generate more quickly? And second, I think you disclosed that as of the end of '14, a little less than 10% of your fulfillment centers are outfitted with Kiva. So I guess, are all of the other fulfillment centers, on a go-forward basis, going to have Kiva? If not, why not? And given the pickup and presumably volume throughput there, does this mean that you can slow down the pacing of buildout there?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. On Prime Now, is our intent to roll out the benefits and functionality globally as quickly as possible, and were able to do that with Prime Now and get to the U.K. faster. We're happy with that. It's not necessarily on comment on AmazonFresh, t
componenttext: Yes, sure. On Prime Now, is our intent to roll out the benefits and functionality globally as quickly as possible, and were able to do that with Prime Now and get to the U.K. faster. We're happy with that. It's not necessarily on comment on AmazonFresh, they're different businesses. So we're happy with the launch in the U.K. and the team did a great job to get that launch and a timely manner. On Kiva, we are up to 30,000 bots at the end of Q3, which is in 13 fulfillment centers. At the end of 2014, we had 15,000 bots. And so we've doubled that amount and we're in 10 warehouses. So part of our intent is to use that more widely, and stay tuned.

componenttext: Yes, sorry. We continue to see really strong usage growth across the board and it's coming from customers of all sizes. We also have recently announced or order, which is our new database software is our fastest-growing service ever. So for a long time, we talked about ranks shift and Aurora is now outpaced that. So we're very excited about what we seeing there.

componenttext: I not be big on the scale of it, but the capital intensity is offset by their density and throughput, so it's a bit of investment that has implications for a lot of the elements of your cost structure. But we are very happy with Kiva. We think it's a great pairing our associates with Kiva robots to do some of the hauling of products within the warehouse has been a great innovation for us. And we think it makes the warehouse jobs better, and I think it makes warehouses more productive.

componenttextpreview: Great. Two questions. So first, our data suggests that U.S. Prime sub growth is growing very rapidly at scale. Just wondering where you think the U.S. Prime sub base is now in the adoption curve. And then the second question is North America EGM growth ac
componenttext: Great. Two questions. So first, our data suggests that U.S. Prime sub growth is growing very rapidly at scale. Just wondering where you think the U.S. Prime sub base is now in the adoption curve. And then the second question is North America EGM growth accelerating again this quarter. We're assuming growth is being driven in part by categories like apparel and consumables versus against perhaps a more mature category like electronics. So the questions are with the vertical mix changing, how should we think about the impact to margins? Are some of the newer and faster growing category structurally higher margin for Amazon than the more mature categories?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't get into too much detail on the components of EGM profitability. I would say that we're seeing strong growth across all of our EGM categories. And we have great teams that are chasing a lot of different product lines and working with vendors
componenttext: Yes, I can't get into too much detail on the components of EGM profitability. I would say that we're seeing strong growth across all of our EGM categories. And we have great teams that are chasing a lot of different product lines and working with vendors to get more selection on the site, both retail and also third party. So it's still a lot of now. On the Prime sub growth, were not updating this statistics. We are very happy with a growth not only in participation, but also purchases and attention, and we had a very successful Prime Day in July that we're really happy was a great event for customers and sellers. So that's all I have on that.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to our Q3 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks.The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to our Q3 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Brian Olsavsky, our CFO. We will be available for questions after our prepared remarks.
The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, October 22, 2015, only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K. 
As you listen to today's conference call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter. During this call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted in our IR website, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2014.
Now I'll turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Phil. I'll begin with comments on our third quarter financial results. Trailing 12 months operating cash flow increased 72% to $9.8 billion. Trailing 12 months free cash flow increased to $5.4 billion, up from $1.1 billion. Trailing 12 months fr
componenttext:
Thanks, Phil. I'll begin with comments on our third quarter financial results. 
Trailing 12 months operating cash flow increased 72% to $9.8 billion. Trailing 12 months free cash flow increased to $5.4 billion, up from $1.1 billion. Trailing 12 months free cash flow, less lease principal repayments, was $3.1 billion, up from an outflow of $99 million. Trailing 12 months free cash flow, less finance lease principal repayments and capital acquired under capital leases, was $637 million, up from an outflow of $2.3 billion. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $4.4 billion.
Capital expenditures does not include the impact of property and equipment acquired under capital and finance lease obligations. These capital expenditures and capital leases reflect additional investments in support of continued business growth due to investments in technology infrastructure, the majority of which is to support AWS, and additional capacity to support our fulfillment operations. The combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 489 million shares, compared with 481 million 1 year ago.
Worldwide revenue grew 23% to $25.4 billion, or 30% excluding the $1.3 billion unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange. Worldwide paid unit growth was 26%. Worldwide active customer accounts was approximately 294 million. Excluding customers who only had 3 orders in the preceding 12-month period, worldwide active customers were approximately 272 million, up from approximately 244 million in the comparable prior year period. Worldwide seller units represented 46% of paid units, up from 42% in the comparable prior year period.
Now I'll discuss operating expenses excluding stock-based compensation. Cost of sales was $16.8 billion or 66.1% of revenue compared with 71.1%. Fulfillment, marketing, technology and content and G&A combined was $7.6 billion or 30.1% of sales, up approximately 50 basis points year-over-year. Fulfillment was $3.1 billion or 12.3% of revenue compared with 12.4%. Tech and content was $2.9 billion or 11.4% of revenue compared with 10.8%. Marketing was $1.2 billion or 4.8% of revenue compared with 4.7%.
Now I'll talk about our segment results. As a reminder, in the first quarter, we changed our reportable segments to report North America, international and Amazon Web Services. Consistent with prior periods, we do not allocate to segments our stock-based compensation or the other operating expense line item.
In the North America segment, revenue grew 28% to $15 billion or 29% excluding foreign exchange. Media revenue grew 8% to $3 billion or 9% excluding foreign exchange.  EGM revenue grew 35% to $11.8 billion. EGM now represents 79% of North America revenues. 
North America segment operating income was $528 million, a 3.5% operating margin, compared to a loss of $60 million in the prior year period. North America segment operating income includes $11 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange.
In the international segment, revenue increased 7% to $8.3 billion. Excluding the $1.3 billion year-over-year unfavorable foreign exchange impact, revenue growth was 24%.
Media revenue decreased 8% to $2.3 billion, or increased 6% excluding foreign exchange. EGM revenue grew 14% to $5.9 billion or 32% excluding foreign exchange. EGM now represents 71% of international revenues.
International segment operating loss was $56 million compared to a loss of $174 million in the prior year period. International segment operating loss includes $64 million of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange.
In the Amazon Web Services segment, revenue grew 78% to $2.1 billion. Amazon Web Services segment operating income was $521 million, a 25% operating margin, compared to $98 million in the prior year period. AWS segment operating income includes $78 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange.
Consolidated segment operating income was $993 million or 3.9% of revenue, up approximately 460 basis points year-over-year. CSOI includes $25 million of favorable impact from foreign exchange. Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation expense and other operating expense. GAAP operating income was $406 million compared to a loss of $544 million in the prior year period. Our income tax expense was $161 million. GAAP net income was $79 million or $0.17 per diluted share compared to the net loss of $437 million or a loss of $0.95 per diluted share.
Turning to the balance sheet. Cash and marketable securities increased $7.5 billion year-over-year to $14.4 billion. Inventory increased 23% to $9 billion. And inventory turns were 8.6, down from 8.9 turns a year ago, as we expanded selection, improved in-stock levels and introduced new product categories. Accounts payable increased 22% to $14.4 billion; and accounts payable days increased 79 from 74 in the prior year.
I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our guidance are the order trends that we've seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors, including a high level of uncertainty surrounding exchange rate fluctuations, as well as the global economy and customer spending. It's not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.
As we described in more detail in our public filings, issues such as settling intercompany balances in foreign currencies among our subsidiaries, unfavorable resolution of legal matters and changes to our effective tax rate can all have material effects on guidance. Our guidance further assumes that we don't include any additional business acquisitions, investments, restructurings or legal settlements, record any further revisions to stock-based compensation estimates and that foreign exchange rates remain approximately where they've been recently. 
For Q4 2015, we expect net sales of between $33.5 billion and $36.75 billion or growth of between 14% and 25%. This guidance anticipates approximately 340 basis points of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates.
GAAP operating income to be between $80 million and $1.28 billion compared to $591 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. This includes approximately $620 million for stock-based compensation and amortization of intangible assets.
We anticipate consolidated segment operating income, which excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense, to be between $700 million and $1.9 billion compared to $1.04 billion in the fourth quarter 2014.
We remain heads down, focused on driving a better customer experience through price selection and convenience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholders. 
Thanks. And with that, Phil, let's move on to questions.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Brian. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question?[ph]

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from Scott Devitt with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from Scott Devitt with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The first question, Brian, international retail growth continues to improve. And I was wondering if you can just talk through some of the dynamics there, understanding that consumption tax in Japan comp. You have some newer markets where you have physical
componenttext: The first question, Brian, international retail growth continues to improve. And I was wondering if you can just talk through some of the dynamics there, understanding that consumption tax in Japan comp. You have some newer markets where you have physical infrastructure now in Europe, and then also the dynamics may be in China as contributors. And then secondly, maybe if you can just -- given how profitable AWS has become, if you can give a framework for thinking about the long-term profitability of that business?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott. Thanks for your questions. On international, yes, you're right. The -- first of all, the FX-neutral growth of 24% year-over-year is up 200 basis points versus Q2 and up 1,100 basis points year-over-year. Some of that is due to the comping of
componenttext: Sure, Scott. Thanks for your questions. On international, yes, you're right. The -- first of all, the FX-neutral growth of 24% year-over-year is up 200 basis points versus Q2 and up 1,100 basis points year-over-year. Some of that is due to the comping of the JP consumption tax increase in April of last year, which we said last year impacted Q2 and Q3 and to -- and not really impacted Q4. So we're seeing the last of that in the comp. But -- and the impact of Prime Day globally, we estimated about 200 basis points, and we saw a pickup in both -- I'll remind you that Prime Day was a global event, so we saw that as international as well. That was a great event for -- a great day for customers, Amazon and sellers alike. But the -- today's international growth is really being driven by Prime adoption, greater selection, greater Prime selection, including FBA. So it's essentially the same playbook as the U.S. The additional Prime features. We launched the Prime Now location in the U.K. this quarter, not materially going to impact the entire continent, but it's a good start. So we like the trends in international, and they mirror many of the same things we see in North America. On AWS, I don't remember your question -- the business model there. Yes, then you talked about margin, it was up sequentially from Q2 from 21.4% to 25%. We're continuing to see great acceleration in the pace of innovation. We've launched 530 new significant features this year, which is more than last year already. We continue to lower prices. We've lowered prices 8 times since we had a large price cut in April of 2014 -- excuse me, April of 2014. And they like -- \the customers are really responding. They like the speed and agility that AWS provides them. They like the new features that we launched, many of which are also -- enable them to lower their cost of infrastructure. Amazon Aurora, 1/10 the price of other high-end commercial databases; a new storage class of Amazon S3 quick site, also very effective and cost-effective products for our customers. So like AWS, the model remains, yes, early days. And we enjoy leading this business, and customers responded well. And we believe we are adding new services and features at a rate faster than many others. And we -- the growth rates and margins will certainly remain lumpy and bumpy as we go forward. But we're very, very encouraged by the business, and so are customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark May with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark May with Citi.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Question, hopefully hasn't been asked already, is around AWS margins were obviously quite strong in the quarter. Can you speak to the sustainability of the margin improvement that we've seen there? And sort of what is your long-term expectations for profi
componenttext: Question, hopefully hasn't been asked already, is around AWS margins were obviously quite strong in the quarter. Can you speak to the sustainability of the margin improvement that we've seen there? And sort of what is your long-term expectations for profit margins for this business? And if you can give a sense of what CapEx for this segment of the business look like in the quarter and kind of the rate of growth, that would be helpful. And then secondly, your employee adds were fairly strong in the quarter as well. I wonder if you could call [ph] any particular areas of -- within the business where you're sort of -- where you're strengthening your hiring efforts.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Phil, I'll take the AWS portion. So I'll sort of echo what Brian said earlier. This is a young and rapidly growing business. And as you've seen, looking backwards, certainly growth rates and margins and capital expenditure timing could be bumpy
componenttext: So this is Phil, I'll take the AWS portion. So I'll sort of echo what Brian said earlier. This is a young and rapidly growing business. And as you've seen, looking backwards, certainly growth rates and margins and capital expenditure timing could be bumpy. We're taking a very long-term view on this business, we're excited about the potential there. And really, the team's focused on just keeping their heads down and continue to accelerate the pace of innovation to try to continue to grow the functionality gap we think we offer. So a lot of hard work going on there. But again, we're taking a long-term view on the business and interested in helping customers as much as possible in that space. On the CapEx, again, we're focused on the ability to drive efficiencies across all of Amazon, but we're also certainly investing in growth. And so on the AWS side, we've got investment going on around the world, certainly additional servers to support the strong growth we have. And some of the expense for things like data centers or new regions could be a little lumpy. We've mentioned a couple of new regions we're working on throughout the world, so that's going on as well.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mark, on your headcount question, you're right, the headcount was up 49% year-over-year, which is higher than Q2, we saw in Q2. This is going to be primarily our ops area. If you exclude ops-related employees, our headcount is growing actually slower than
componenttext: Mark, on your headcount question, you're right, the headcount was up 49% year-over-year, which is higher than Q2, we saw in Q2. This is going to be primarily our ops area. If you exclude ops-related employees, our headcount is growing actually slower than our FX-neutral growth rate of 30%. So what's going on in ops is we've added 14 net fulfillment centers this year, bringing the total to 123 globally. We've added four sort centers in the U.S., bringing the U.S. footprint to 23. We're staffing earlier in those locations. We're in good shape for the holidays and ready to go. The other issue is -- or another reason that we're also doing a lot of conversion of temp workers to full-time workers purposely. This is a metric pooling them into full-time hire, so it is a little bit higher due to that program.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm tempted to ask about the long-term margins for AWS, but I won't. Could you talk about 2 areas? One, EGM growth in North America, it's accelerated strongly. Any color behind what's -- in particular, categories that are driving that? And secondly, there
componenttext: I'm tempted to ask about the long-term margins for AWS, but I won't. Could you talk about 2 areas? One, EGM growth in North America, it's accelerated strongly. Any color behind what's -- in particular, categories that are driving that? And secondly, there's been -- you've made some public comments in the last 8 months about some -- on the retail side about investments internationally, particularly in India. Could you just refresh us on what kind of levels of spend you're interested in targeting in that market? And then maybe as part of that, any comments on China and your -- how well you think you're doing there now?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. On EGM growth, I won't call out any particular categories, but it is a direct reflection of our efforts to grow selection both our retail selection and also our third-party, particularly FBA, which is also Prime eligible. And then just the responsiv
componenttext: Sure. On EGM growth, I won't call out any particular categories, but it is a direct reflection of our efforts to grow selection both our retail selection and also our third-party, particularly FBA, which is also Prime eligible. And then just the responsiveness of our customers, that's our share Prime customers to the EGM product line. So we're very encouraged with the EGM growth. And on India, we'll not -- excuse me, I won't give specific dollar numbers around investment, but I can give you an update on India. We're really encouraged with what we seeing both on the customer side and the seller side. On the customer side, seller -- excuse me, active customer accounts were up 230% year-over-year. We're in the middle of the Diwali season, that is going really well. Sales are 4x where they were last year, so customers are responding greatly this year. We continue to invest. We've been adding products at a rate of 40,000 products per day so far this year. And just as big as the number of sellers. The sellers, number of sellers has grown more than 250% year-over-year. 90% of those sellers are using our logistics and warehouse services. And as a result, we've tripled our fulfillment capacity year-over-year. So we are very encouraged, as I said, last quarter in India, and continue to invest there heavily.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mark, I think you asked about China as well. This is Phil. So we'll continue to work on some of the items we've been talking about for a couple of quarters now. So the team has some interesting ideas, really focused on making Amazon a trusted conduit for
componenttext: Mark, I think you asked about China as well. This is Phil. So we'll continue to work on some of the items we've been talking about for a couple of quarters now. So the team has some interesting ideas, really focused on making Amazon a trusted conduit for Chinese customers to access authentic international branded products and things that the customers can't get. I think AmazonGlobal store continues to expand the selection there. We added about another 400,000 items to that store this quarter, and continue to focus on using our global network of vendors to be able to get those products to customers. We continue to test store on Tmall as well. And the team has some other ideas, but that's what we're talking about so far.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan with UBS Investment Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan with UBS Investment Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you call out, in terms of the 3P business, what you're seeing in terms of third-party sellers maybe needing to make more and more of their goods Prime eligible, what the economics of that might be in terms of creating a tailwind for the business, and
componenttext: Can you call out, in terms of the 3P business, what you're seeing in terms of third-party sellers maybe needing to make more and more of their goods Prime eligible, what the economics of that might be in terms of creating a tailwind for the business, and how should we think about that evolving over the next couple of years?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Eric. What I can tell you is the 3P percent of revenue continues to grow. We're now up to 46% of paid units, which is up 400 basis points year-over-year and 100 basis point sequentially off Q2. We feel that Prime and FBA are -- reinforce each other.
componenttext: Sure, Eric. What I can tell you is the 3P percent of revenue continues to grow. We're now up to 46% of paid units, which is up 400 basis points year-over-year and 100 basis point sequentially off Q2. We feel that Prime and FBA are -- reinforce each other. They're inextricably linked. FBA has Prime selection, and Prime growth attracts more FBA sellers. So we have seen growth in FBA. It increases our Prime fast-track eligible selection, which we like and customers like. So we like what we see on the third-party side.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We didn't see the acceleration in EGM. I was just wondering if some of the local delivery and Prime Now is driving that acceleration? Is that having a big impact on your business? And down the road, do you think the delivery infrastructure will be valuabl
componenttext: We didn't see the acceleration in EGM. I was just wondering if some of the local delivery and Prime Now is driving that acceleration? Is that having a big impact on your business? And down the road, do you think the delivery infrastructure will be valuable and maybe delivering third-party and other units?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. So it's still pretty early for a lot of the really expedited delivery options. We've been working on our network for about 20 years to be able to enable some of the really fast delivery with things like Prime Now. But at this point, we're in
componenttext: This is Phil. So it's still pretty early for a lot of the really expedited delivery options. We've been working on our network for about 20 years to be able to enable some of the really fast delivery with things like Prime Now. But at this point, we're in a relatively small list of cities, but it's expanding pretty fast. I think we launched a couple more Prime Now cities just today, so that brings us up to about 17 across the globe. On the next day or same day here in the U.S., we continue to expand that as well. But we think that those fast options add us to the consideration set of a customer's purchase on some purchases that we might not otherwise be included in. But at this point, we're still working on that and kind of getting it up to speed. So nothing specific to call out on that. On the other part of your question, we continue to work on the network around the world, but can't respond to any of the rumors and speculation.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Peck with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Peck with SunTrust.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is for Kunal for Bob. A quick question on India. Is there any change or any indication that there might be a change in the regulatory framework that would allow you to go direct?
componenttext: This is for Kunal for Bob. A quick question on India. Is there any change or any indication that there might be a change in the regulatory framework that would allow you to go direct?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. I don't know that we have anything to comment on with that.
componenttext: This is Phil. I don't know that we have anything to comment on with that.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask, the most frequent investor question and concern that we get is when will Amazon flip back to its heavier spending and investment ways from 2014 and earlier? So I just wanted to ask you, is that a legitimate question, do you think? Or
componenttext: I just wanted to ask, the most frequent investor question and concern that we get is when will Amazon flip back to its heavier spending and investment ways from 2014 and earlier? So I just wanted to ask you, is that a legitimate question, do you think? Or are you now at a point of scale and market share and maturity that you can sustainably manage the heavy investment while still delivering material profit?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Doug. Well, I would point out that this quarter showed a lot of innovation, a lot of new products and features and a lot of investment. We've already talked about India. But domestically, we are -- excuse me, globally, we are investing very h
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Doug. Well, I would point out that this quarter showed a lot of innovation, a lot of new products and features and a lot of investment. We've already talked about India. But domestically, we are -- excuse me, globally, we are investing very heavily on our Prime platform, both in North America and international. And that includes video content and regional content, Prime Music. Phil just said the Prime Now has expanded to 14 metro areas. We've had same-day delivery now in 16 metro areas. We built 14 new fulfillment centers. We've launched multiple devices including e-readers, tablets that are priced under $50 -- Echo, Dash Button. So there is a lot of investment going on, and they will be continued especially related to Prime. On the AWS side, as I said, we have 530 new features so far this year. So innovation and investment will continue and can be lumpy. I hate to use that word again, but it could be lumpy over time. The other dynamic in our company, though, is definitely working on cost reductions and efficiency. I think you'll see a lot of that in this quarter's P&L and in our capital efficiency, both in the warehouse world and also in infrastructure. So we will continue to work on costs. The good thing about 30% revenue growth is it gives you a lot more cost to work on as well. So we will -- I would say it's not as much as a pendulum as maybe it's been portrayed. It's more of a constant. The investment will -- it sometimes ebbs and flows, but the cost reductions will be a constant presence, and the increase in customer experience and shortening the time to delivery and making the customer experience better.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys had the Kindle store in Brazil since December of 2012. Just curious about the learnings around that and kind of what benchmarks are you analyzing as you kind of try to determine whether or not to invest further in a larger Brazil store? And then
componenttext: You guys had the Kindle store in Brazil since December of 2012. Just curious about the learnings around that and kind of what benchmarks are you analyzing as you kind of try to determine whether or not to invest further in a larger Brazil store? And then the second one, just curious for comments on international Prime sub-growth. It sounds like sub -- Prime subs are growing really well. Like a couple quarters ago, you mentioned how they're growing over 50%. Is that still the case? And if so, what's driving that faster international Prime sub-growth?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the Brazil side -- this is Phil. We've had the Kindle store in Brazil for a while. I think we look at all of our investments with an eye towards trying to maximize long-term free cash flow at strong returns on invested capital. So that's across the
componenttext: So on the Brazil side -- this is Phil. We've had the Kindle store in Brazil for a while. I think we look at all of our investments with an eye towards trying to maximize long-term free cash flow at strong returns on invested capital. So that's across the board. That's kind of the criteria we're using, making sure we're building things that customers love that can have attractive financial returns over time, can persist for a long time. And if they work, can be big. So that's kind of the metrics we're using, there's nothing specific to call out to Brazil, though.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And this is Brian. We're not going to update our Prime subscription growth beyond what we said last year, at the end of last year, which last year, in the year, when we raised prices early in 2014, the global growth rate was 53% and North America growth r
componenttext: And this is Brian. We're not going to update our Prime subscription growth beyond what we said last year, at the end of last year, which last year, in the year, when we raised prices early in 2014, the global growth rate was 53% and North America growth rate was 50%. So by default, the international growth rate was higher. We like the adoption of Prime internationally. It's helped by additional selection that's available for fast-track shipment including FBA. So that flywheel is working. We've also launched video benefits most recently in Japan, but we hadn't in U.K. and Germany. We continue to launch other Prime benefits, Amazon Pantry in Japan and Germany this quarter. We launched Prime Now in the U.K. So it's very similar to the U.S. story, potentially time lagged a bit, but we are seeing the same customer adoption and impact on growth rates.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next caller is Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next caller is Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. So you have told us that you have tens of millions of Prime users, that you are investing heavily in Prime. Now at this scale and with the 50%-plus growth rate that you just mentioned, if you roll the clock 2 or 3 years, one can see Pr
componenttext: I have 2 questions. So you have told us that you have tens of millions of Prime users, that you are investing heavily in Prime. Now at this scale and with the 50%-plus growth rate that you just mentioned, if you roll the clock 2 or 3 years, one can see Prime penetration in the markets like the U.S. starting to saturate us, there are just so many homes in the country. How should we think about the level of investment in Prime once you have reached full penetration? Are there components that are driven primarily through customer acquisition? And what's the right way to think about that? And secondly, what are the economic drivers that justify the business case for Prime Now? I don't expect you to give us any numbers, I've learned that in the last few years. But what are the components of the customer life cycle value calculation, or whatever calculation that you make, to justify someone dropping a box with that $15 order to a customer?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you, Carlos. First on what I'll classify as Prime demographics. So yes, we still think there's a lot of people in the country who are not Prime members, and we're anxious to have them try it and sign up and join. The other thing that we see is
componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Carlos. First on what I'll classify as Prime demographics. So yes, we still think there's a lot of people in the country who are not Prime members, and we're anxious to have them try it and sign up and join. The other thing that we see is that with our vast offering of selection and faster and faster shipping programs, we have a more competitive offering for many things that they buy. So there's a share of wallet element to it as well, over time, that we are looking to be more useful to customers all the time. On your comment about the economic drivers of Prime Now, you know what I'll say is customers really value it. It's not our entire selection. It's tens of thousands of items that they may need on a daily basis. We think it's an interesting part of the selection offer for Prime. And it's, in many ways, something that we can do that others can't because it's a natural evolution of our 20-year effort to grow our fulfillment center network. And our scale, quite frankly, makes it possible to even offer this to customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Neil Doshi with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Neil Doshi with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit more about India and what's kind of the opportunity there that you see? There's tremendous amount of -- tremendous middle-class there that the distribution can be very challenging. So is that an area where we can see Amazon reall
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit more about India and what's kind of the opportunity there that you see? There's tremendous amount of -- tremendous middle-class there that the distribution can be very challenging. So is that an area where we can see Amazon really building out the last mile? And then there's been some reports of an Amazon potentially trying to close the gap in terms of delivery and deliver it sooner. On the grocery side, what's the impetus there? And can we see -- how's the recent markets been trending on the grocery side that you've launched recently?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the India question. So again, I -- India is a different market and does not have a lot of the same ready fulfillment options that some other countries did. We see that as an opportunity, an opportunity that we can build, and we can bring to sell
componenttext: I'll take the India question. So again, I -- India is a different market and does not have a lot of the same ready fulfillment options that some other countries did. We see that as an opportunity, an opportunity that we can build, and we can bring to sellers. And as I believe I already mentioned, we like what we see. We're very encouraged. Customer accounts, active customer accounts are up 230% year-over-year. And sellers, number of sellers is up 250% year-over-year, 90% of those sellers use our logistics and warehouse services, as we mentioned, which has caused us to triple our fulfillment capacity. And we're happy to do so. We like what we see in India. We think we have -- we're attractive both to customers and to sellers, and we like our position.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Phil. So on the grocery side, for Fresh, we're in a handful of metropolitan areas here in the U.S. It's been a relatively measured rollout by Amazon standards. We continue to work on the customer experience and making sure we're really delivering
componenttext: This is Phil. So on the grocery side, for Fresh, we're in a handful of metropolitan areas here in the U.S. It's been a relatively measured rollout by Amazon standards. We continue to work on the customer experience and making sure we're really delivering a quality experience for shoppers. And we're also working on the economics. And so we continue to work on that, but not much new to add right now.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can give us a sense how some of the recent announcements from FedEx and UPS about pricing during the holidays and the structure of some of the third-party relationships might impact you. And given the investments that you've made in
componenttext: I was wondering if you can give us a sense how some of the recent announcements from FedEx and UPS about pricing during the holidays and the structure of some of the third-party relationships might impact you. And given the investments that you've made in your own fulfillment infrastructure, how much of a competitive advantage you feel like you've got during the holiday season as other retailers have to -- or better more, directly exposed to these changes have to deal with it?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No comment on the pricing. I would say that we have 23 sort centers which allows us to control a lot more of our shipments for longer. But we certainly value our relationships with USPS, FedEx, UPS and other global carriers. So I'm looking forward to a gr
componenttext: No comment on the pricing. I would say that we have 23 sort centers which allows us to control a lot more of our shipments for longer. But we certainly value our relationships with USPS, FedEx, UPS and other global carriers. So I'm looking forward to a great holiday season.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Aaron Kessler with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Aaron Kessler with Raymond James.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just quickly on -- if you can talk about some of the more experimental projects you work on, I guess the travel business you're kind of in again for a few months and then got out of. Also maybe just with restaurant, providing restaurant delivery. How do y
componenttext: Just quickly on -- if you can talk about some of the more experimental projects you work on, I guess the travel business you're kind of in again for a few months and then got out of. Also maybe just with restaurant, providing restaurant delivery. How do you view the services? They're not necessarily core to what you do. Obviously, you can provide those services. But how should we think about these types of investments longer term?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on destinations, we're constantly trying new things and testing and measuring and iterating here at Amazon. And we learned a lot, but we discontinued that. On the restaurant delivery, we've had it for a couple months here in Seattle, and recently annou
componenttext: So on destinations, we're constantly trying new things and testing and measuring and iterating here at Amazon. And we learned a lot, but we discontinued that. On the restaurant delivery, we've had it for a couple months here in Seattle, and recently announced it Portland. And it fits very well with Prime Now. So at this point, it's pretty small, but something we're excited to do for customers. We think it'll be helpful for them. And we're happy to take advantage of some of the competencies we've built with Prime Now, with our fulfillment network so far.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Pitz with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Pitz with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Some questions on video. Any color, such as engagement on the recent launch of video products in Japan, including the Fire TV, the Fire TV Stick and Prime video. And also, any general updates on your video content strategy or view on stand-alone streaming
componenttext: Some questions on video. Any color, such as engagement on the recent launch of video products in Japan, including the Fire TV, the Fire TV Stick and Prime video. And also, any general updates on your video content strategy or view on stand-alone streaming separate from Prime?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that one. This is Brian. So no specific callouts in Japan. I would say that we are still very bullish on our Prime Instant Video, the -- especially our new original content we've created. We think it's been critically acclaimed and also a b
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that one. This is Brian. So no specific callouts in Japan. I would say that we are still very bullish on our Prime Instant Video, the -- especially our new original content we've created. We think it's been critically acclaimed and also a big hit with customers. Man in the High Castle is coming out shortly, as is the second season of Transparent, which won Emmys this year. So we're really excited about the creative team we've assembled and the products that they've been able to bring to Prime customers. And we still like the customer reaction. Free trial conversion rates are higher when Prime members stream, and they also renew at a higher rate for their annual subscriptions. So again, that's very important to us as well, and we're very happy with the results.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ben Schachter with Macquarie Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ben Schachter with Macquarie Equity Research.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Prime has done remarkably well with folks willing to pay $99 upfront. But you expect to have different offerings for different cohorts? In other words, right now, Prime is sort of a one-size-fits-all model. Could we see different pricing models for dif
componenttext: So Prime has done remarkably well with folks willing to pay $99 upfront. But you expect to have different offerings for different cohorts? In other words, right now, Prime is sort of a one-size-fits-all model. Could we see different pricing models for different demographics in the future? And then separately, can you also talk about how shipping leverage changes during the holiday season when shoppers tend to order more items per transaction?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So this is Phil. On the Prime pricing, we do have a few different programs for different demographic today with programs like Prime Student or Prime family, which -- or parent, which we're very excited about. I can't speculate as to what we'd do in
componenttext: Sure. So this is Phil. On the Prime pricing, we do have a few different programs for different demographic today with programs like Prime Student or Prime family, which -- or parent, which we're very excited about. I can't speculate as to what we'd do in the future, but Prime is a program that's really important for us, and we're working hard every day to continue to build selection there and to continue to make Prime better. And so hopefully, you should see that in the list of things we've launched recently and the kind of continued cadence of making the services we have better. We just added a lot of new music in our Prime Music program. And as Brian mentioned, some of the upcoming programming should be pretty good in the fall. The Man in the High Castle was actually our most watched pilot, so we're excited about that one as well. So continue to work on Prime. On the shipping side, no, I would say it's a difficult equation. Yes, order size can go up, but we ship a lot of toys and bigger items, so it's hard to predict what that looks like. But having the density, having the sort centers has certainly helped our cost structure in that area, and having inventory closer to our customers.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Stephen Ju with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Ju with Credit Suisse.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, it seems like you guys are rolling out Prime Now as well as product verticals internationally fairly quickly as -- especially if you measure it versus the pace you've have for Fresh or your other international older territories. So am I reading too
componenttext: Brian, it seems like you guys are rolling out Prime Now as well as product verticals internationally fairly quickly as -- especially if you measure it versus the pace you've have for Fresh or your other international older territories. So am I reading too much into this? Or have you guys put in place different processes to iterate more quickly? And second, I think you disclosed that as of the end of '14, a little less than 10% of your fulfillment centers are outfitted with Kiva. So I guess, are all of your other fulfillment centers on a go-forward basis going to have Kiva? If not, why not? And given the pickup and presumably volume throughput there, does this mean you can slow down the pacing of build-out there?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. On Prime Now, it is our intent to roll out the benefits and functionality globally as quickly as possible, and we're able to do that with Prime Now and get to the U.K. faster. We're happy with that. It's not necessarily a comment on AmazonFresh
componenttext: Yes, sure. On Prime Now, it is our intent to roll out the benefits and functionality globally as quickly as possible, and we're able to do that with Prime Now and get to the U.K. faster. We're happy with that. It's not necessarily a comment on AmazonFresh, just -- they're different businesses. So we're happy with the launch in the U.K., and the team did a great job to get that launched on a timely manner. On Kiva, we are up to 30,000 box at the end of Q3, which is in 13 fulfillment centers. At the end of 2014, we had 15,000 box, so we've doubled that amount, and they were in 10 warehouses. So our intent is to use that more widely, and stay tuned.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ron Josey with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ron Josey with JMP Securities.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just quickly on [indiscernible] growth, accelerated 26% this year. I realize that these are comps, but anything significantly higher or anything that happened this quarter? I know Prime they couldn't be it, but wondering if that was a reason? And then on
componenttext: Just quickly on [indiscernible] growth, accelerated 26% this year. I realize that these are comps, but anything significantly higher or anything that happened this quarter? I know Prime they couldn't be it, but wondering if that was a reason? And then on AWS usage, just wondering if you can update on usage. Really, last quarter, you mentioned usage was growing faster than revenue. I'm wondering if that's the same case this quarter.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Phil. On the unit site, you did see in units move at a rate that's kind of highly correlated with revenue there. Keep in mind AWS and some of the other rental type of offerings don't generate units, so we don't count those, but we did see -- ce
componenttext: So this is Phil. On the unit site, you did see in units move at a rate that's kind of highly correlated with revenue there. Keep in mind AWS and some of the other rental type of offerings don't generate units, so we don't count those, but we did see -- certainly saw some additional units as a result of Prime Day. And on a longer-term bigger basis, the continued growth of Prime, the continued selection expansion is helping with the units growth there. Sorry, was there a second part to your question?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on AWS unit growth. I think last quarter you said it was growing faster than revenue. I'm wondering if that's still the case here.
componenttext: Just on AWS unit growth. I think last quarter you said it was growing faster than revenue. I'm wondering if that's still the case here.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to see really -- yes, sorry. We continue to see really strong usage growth across the board and it's coming from customers of all sizes. We also have recently announced that Aurora, which is our new database software, is our fastest-growing se
componenttext: We continue to see really -- yes, sorry. We continue to see really strong usage growth across the board and it's coming from customers of all sizes. We also have recently announced that Aurora, which is our new database software, is our fastest-growing service ever. So for a long time, we talked about red shifts and Aurora is now outpaced that. So we're very excited about what we seeing there.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Youssef Squali with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Youssef Squali with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions. First, with the court striking down the safe harbor provision between the U.S. and the EU, how do you see changes to European data storage requirement affecting AWS potentially? And on the Kiva question asked earlier, can you just may
componenttext: Two quick questions. First, with the court striking down the safe harbor provision between the U.S. and the EU, how do you see changes to European data storage requirement affecting AWS potentially? And on the Kiva question asked earlier, can you just maybe help us understand the capital intensity of a -- an FC using Kiva versus one that's not?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Phil. I'll take the safe harbor question with AWS. With the EU-approved AWS data protection agreement and model clauses we have in place, AWS customers can keep running their global operations using AWS and be in compliance with E law. I think
componenttext: So this is Phil. I'll take the safe harbor question with AWS. With the EU-approved AWS data protection agreement and model clauses we have in place, AWS customers can keep running their global operations using AWS and be in compliance with E law. I think your second question was about the capital intensity of Kiva -- yes.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Right.
componenttext: Yes. Right.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't want to be vague on the scale of it, but they are -- the capital intensity is offset by their density and throughput. So it's a bit of investment that has implications for a lot of the elements to your cost structure. But we're very happy wit
componenttext: Yes, I don't want to be vague on the scale of it, but they are -- the capital intensity is offset by their density and throughput. So it's a bit of investment that has implications for a lot of the elements to your cost structure. But we're very happy with Kiva. We think it's a great -- pairing our associates with Kiva robots to do some of the hauling of products within the warehouse has been a great innovation for us. And we think it makes the warehouse jobs better, and I think it makes our warehouses more productive.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Our last question comes from John Blackledge with Cowen and Company.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Two questions. So first, our data suggests that U.S. Prime sub-growth is growing very rapidly at scale. Just wondering where you think the U.S. Prime sub-base is now in the adoption curve. And then the second question is North America EGM growth ac
componenttext: Great. Two questions. So first, our data suggests that U.S. Prime sub-growth is growing very rapidly at scale. Just wondering where you think the U.S. Prime sub-base is now in the adoption curve. And then the second question is North America EGM growth accelerating again this quarter. We're assuming growth is being driven in part by categories like apparel and consumables versus perhaps a more mature category, like electronics. So the questions are with the vertical mix changing, how should we think about the impact to margins? Are some of the newer and faster-growing categories structurally higher margin for Amazon than the more mature categories?

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't get into too much detail on the components of EGM profitability. I would say that we're seeing strong growth across all of our EGM categories. And we have great teams that are chasing a lot of different product lines and working with vendors
componenttext: Yes, I can't get into too much detail on the components of EGM profitability. I would say that we're seeing strong growth across all of our EGM categories. And we have great teams that are chasing a lot of different product lines and working with vendors to get more selection on the site, both retail and also third party. So there's still a lot of room there. On the Prime sub-growth, we're not updating this statistics. We are very happy with the growth, not only in participation, but also purchases and retention. And we had a very successful Prime Day in July that we're really happy was a great event for customers and sellers. So that's all I have on that.

headline: Amazon.com, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: All right. Thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.
